Duplicating all the styles involving colors is impractical, especially if you change the design of the button later. With hue, we can replace blue2 with hue2, blue8/70 with hue8/70 and so on. Then we can set the color scale using the hue property.

# [preview=md] import 'util/styles' global css body d:hflex ja:center inset:0 # --- tag Button css px:4 py:2 rd:md cursor:pointer c:white text-shadow:0px 1px hue8/70 bg:hue5 @hover:hue6 bd:1px solid hue6 <self> <span> <slot> imba.mount do <> <Button[hue:blue]> "Button" <Button[hue:red]> "Button" <Button[hue:green]> "Button" <Button[hue:amber hue@hover:purple]> "Hover me"

children.head: /docs/css/properties/hue
children.name: slashdocsslashcssslashpropertiesslashhue
children.html: In addition to the default built in colors, hue0,hue1,...,hue9 refers to the color scale set by the hue property. Setting hue:amber in css, will make hue2 refer to amber2 inside all elements that are affected by this style. The hue(n) color values supports an alpha value with the forward-slash syntax like hue4/40

children.html: <element data=value>

children.title: Type annotations
children.head: Type annotations
children.name: type-annotations
children.html:
When you are dealing with known data-structures it can be useful to set the type of the data property for better auto-completions and warnings:

tag movie-item prop data\Movie <self> <em> data.title <div> for movie in movies # will warn if movie is not of type Movie <movie-item data=movie>

children.title: Convenience getters
children.head: Convenience getters
children.name: convenience-getters
children.html:
Sometimes when working with complex data objects it might be useful to define some getters to alias nested properties of your data.

tag movie-item prop data\Movie get director do data.director get genres do data.genres <self> <em> data.title <a href="/people/{director.id}"> director.name <div> for genre in genres <span> genre.title

children.title: Overriding
children.head: Overriding
children.name: overriding
children.html:
If you want to do something when setting data, you can easily create a setter and getter:

tag movie-item set data value #data = value console.log "movie was set",value get data #data

The memoized dom works in such a way that the setter will only be triggered when the value actually changes. If you set the property manually outside of rendering, the setter will be called every time, even if the value has not changed:

tag app <self> <div> for movie in movies # manually set card.data when clicking an item <movie-item data=movie @click=($card.data = movie)> <movie-card$card>

In this case, the movie-item data setter will only be called when their data actually changes, even if we render the list a million times. But if you click a movie-item 10 times, the movie-card.data property will be set 10 times. This is only really a challenge if you do something computationally expensive in the data setter itself. In that case you can just check if something has changed:

tag movie-card set data value if #data != value #data = value # ... load more info about the movie? get data #data

Since Imba embraces the concepts of memoization we have the =? operator that is shorthand for the pattern above.

if item.propname =? value # item.propname is now set to value, # and was previously set to something else yes

children.title: Usage
children.head: Usage
children.name: usage
children.html:
The default convention in imba is to use the data property on elements to pass in the state/data they are supposed to represent. In this example we pass in the movie object through the data property:

tag movie-item # using references to data <self> <em> data.title <div> for movie in movies <movie-item data=movie>

However, there is nothing special about the data property, besides it being declared for all elements. It is just a plain property. If you prefer to use more descriptive properties you are free to do so:

tag movie-item prop movie # using references to data <self> <em> movie.title <div> for movie in movies <movie-item movie=movie>

Declaring the property with prop movie is not strictly needed, but will give you auto-completions and get rid of warnings about a missing movie property in the tooling.

children.title: Multiline Strings
children.head: Multiline Strings
children.name: multiline-strings
children.html:
Regular string literals can be written over multiple lines, but line breaks are ignored.

let string = 'one two three' # => 'onetwo three'

If you need a string that spans several lines and includes line breaks, use a sequence of characters surrounded by ''' or """

let string = ''' This string is written over multiple lines ''' # => 'This string\nis written over\nmultiple lines'

Multiline strings preserves indentation, but only relative to the least indented line:

let string = ''' First level is ignored This is indented Not indented '''

children.title: Template Strings
children.head: Template Strings
children.name: template-strings
children.html: `string text` # multiple lines `string text line 1 string text line 2` # interpolated expression `string text {expression} string text` # tagged template method`string text {expression} string text`

children.title: Tagged templates
children.head: Tagged templates
children.name: tagged-templates
children.html: Tagged templates from JavaScript are on the roadmap, but not currently supported.

children.title: Dimension Strings
children.head: Dimension Strings
children.name: dimension-strings
children.html:
let length = 100px let progress = 87% let dynamic = (window.innerWidth)px

Dimensions are numbers with a unit attached to it. They are compiled and treated as regular strings. When dealing with styles it is nice to be able to write offset = (point.x)px instead of offset = "{point.x}px".

Time-based units ms, s, and fps are compiled to millisecond-based numbers.

10s # 10000 250ms # 250 5s - 150ms # 4850 60fps # 16.66666

children.title: /api/String
children.head: /api/String
children.name: slashapislashstring
children.html:
let single = 'single quotes' let double = "double quotes" let interpolation = "string has {double}" let template = `current version is {imba.version}`

Imba uses {} for string interpolation while JavaScript uses ${}. If you want interpolated strings with literal curly-braces, remember to escape them with \. Other than that, the String type is identical to String in JavaScript. See documentation at MDN.

children.title: Durations
children.head: Durations
children.name: durations
children.html:
Numbers with time units ms, s, and fps are normalised to milliseconds.

10s # 10000 250ms # 250 5s - 150ms # 4850 60fps # 16.66666

children.title: Numeric Separators
children.head: Numeric Separators
children.name: numeric-separators
children.html:
You can use _ as a separator inside numbers for improved readability.

let budget = 120_000_000 let spent = 123_150_077.59 let hex = 0xA0_B0_C0 let binary = 0b0010_1100

children.head: /api/Number
children.name: slashapislashnumber
children.html:
let integer = 42 let float = 42.10 let hex = 0x00 let binary = 0b0010110

The Number type is identical to Number in JavaScript. See documentation at MDN.

children.title: Create config file
children.head: Create config file
children.name: create-config-file
children.html:
Create an imbaconfig.json at the root of your imba project. Right next to your package.json and readme.md files.

{ "theme": { "colors": { } } }

Any changes made to the imbaconfig.json file will require you to restart your localhost server to take effect.

children.title: Aliasing colors
children.head: Aliasing colors
children.name: aliasing-colors
children.html:
We can create an alias for the indigo color called primary in this way.

{ "theme": { "colors": { "primary": "indigo" } } }

Now we can use primary instead of indigo to set the indigo color.

<h1[c:primary4]> "hello world!"

We can also override default color keywords. We can make gray an alias for warmer instead of the default gray colors.

{ "theme": { "colors": { "gray": "warmer" } } }

children.title: Defining custom colors
children.head: Defining custom colors
children.name: defining-custom-colors
children.html:
We can create our own color keywords with specified tint values.

{ "theme": { "colors": { "coral": { "0": "hsl(40,33%,98%)", "1": "hsl(28,61%,94%)", "2": "hsl(12,62%,88%)", "3": "hsl(10,54%,76%)", "4": "hsl(6,56%,65%)", "5": "hsl(5,49%,54%)", "6": "hsl(4,49%,44%)", "7": "hsl(4,50%,34%)", "8": "hsl(4,50%,24%)", "9": "hsl(6,52%,15%)" } } } }

We will then be able to use our own color keyword as we would use the default color keywords.

<h1[c:coral7/70]> "hello world!"

Any unspecified tint will be interpolated automatically. So the configuration below will produce a similar result.

{ "theme": { "colors": { "coral": { "0": "hsl(40,33%,98%)", "4": "hsl(6,56%,65%)", "9": "hsl(6,52%,15%)" } } } }

children.title: Color Theming
children.head: Color Theming
children.name: color-theming
children.html: Imba already contains color keywords, but you may also create aliases for color keywords, make your own keywords, or redefine the default keywords to new color values.

children.title: /docs/css/values/color
children.head: /docs/css/values/color
children.name: slashdocsslashcssslashvaluesslashcolor
children.html:
The color CSS data-type represents a color in the sRGB color space. Colors can be defined in all the same ways as in plain css. In addition, imba as built-in support for named colors hand-crafted by the great people behind Tailwind. All named colors come in 10 different shades, named from color0 up to color9. You can hover over each color below to see their name:

Just like other colors like #7A4ACF, hsl(120,90%,45%), rgba(120,255,176), these named colors can be used anywhere in your styles where a color value is expected.
